metadata.title: Aligning Large Multi-Modal Model with Robust Instruction Tuning
metadata.abstract: Despite the promising progress in multi-modal tasks, current large multi-modal models (LMM) are prone to hallucinating inconsistent descriptions with respect to the associated image and human instructions. This paper addresses this issue by introducing the first large and diverse visual instruction tuning dataset, named Large-scale Robust Visual (LRV)-Instruction . Our dataset consists of 120k visual instructions generated by GPT4, covering 16 vision-and-language tasks with open-ended instructions and answers. Unlike existing studies that primarily focus on positive instruction samples, we design LRV-Instruction to include both positive and negative instructions for more robust visual instruction tuning. Our negative instructions are designed at two semantic levels: (i) Nonexistent Element Manipulation and (ii) Existent Element Manipulation . To efficiently measure the hallucination generated by LMMs, we propose GPT4-Assisted Visual Instruction Evaluation (GAVIE) , a novel approach to evaluate visual instruction tuning without the need for human-annotated groundtruth answers and can adapt to diverse instruction formats. We conduct comprehensive experiments to investigate the hallucination of LMMs. Our results demonstrate that existing LMMs exhibit significant hallucination when presented with our negative instructions, particularly with Existent Element Manipulation instructions. Moreover, by finetuning MiniGPT4 on LRV-Instruction , we successfully mitigate hallucination while improving performance on public datasets using less training data compared to state-of-the-art methods. Additionally, we observed that a balanced ratio of positive and negative instances in the training data leads to a more robust model. Our project link is available at this link.

grobid.contents: Aligning Large Multi-Modal Model with Robust Instruction Tuning Fuxiao Liu University of Maryland College Park Kevin Lin Microsoft Corporation Linjie Li lindsey.li@microsoft.com Microsoft Corporation Jianfeng Wang Microsoft Corporation Yaser Yacoob University of Maryland College Park Lijuan Wang lijuanw@microsoft.com Microsoft Corporation Aligning Large Multi-Modal Model with Robust Instruction Tuning Despite the promising progress in multi-modal tasks, current large multi-modal models (LMM) are prone to hallucinating inconsistent descriptions with respect to the associated image and human instructions. This paper addresses this issue by introducing the first large and diverse visual instruction tuning dataset, named Large-scale Robust Visual (LRV)-Instruction. Our dataset consists of 120k visual instructions generated by GPT4, covering 16 vision-and-language tasks with openended instructions and answers. Unlike existing studies that primarily focus on positive instruction samples, we design LRV-Instruction to include both positive and negative instructions for more robust visual instruction tuning. Our negative instructions are designed at two semantic levels: (i) Nonexistent Element Manipulation and (ii) Existent Element Manipulation. To efficiently measure the hallucination generated by LMMs, we propose GPT4-Assisted Visual Instruction Evaluation (GAVIE), a novel approach to evaluate visual instruction tuning without the need for human-annotated groundtruth answers and can adapt to diverse instruction formats. Under review. Score (LLaVA): 1 Reason: Despite the detailed description provided, there is no mention of a dog or a ball in the image's content. Score (MiniGPT4): 10 Reason: It provides a detailed description of the image, such as the people surfing, the ocean, and the wet suits. Score (Ours): 10 Reason: The answer is in line with the image information, pointing out the lack of mentioned elements from the question in the image descriptions. Score (LLaVA): 10 Reason: It followed the instruction and directly described a dog playing with a ball on the shore, which was the exact scenario asked for in the instruction. Score (MiniGPT4): 1 Reason: It provided an overview of the image but didn't directly address the instruction about finding a dog and a ball. Score (Ours): 10 Reason: The answer directly responds to the question. GAVIE Relevancy Score(0-10) Accuracy Score(0-10) E v a lu a te E v a lu a te LLaVA MiniGPT4Instruction (Nonexistent Element Manipulation):A hot air balloon can be spotted above the tall tree.MiniGPT4: People are standing in a clearing, surrounded by green trees and lush vegetation. The image is clear and well-lit. The sun is shining, casting a warm, golden light over everything.LLaVA: The presence of the hot air balloon above the tall trees in the background suggests that this location could be a popular spot for recreational activities or sightseeing, attracting tourists and nature enthusiasts. InstructBLIP: Yes, a hot air balloon can be spotted above the tall trees. MMGPT: In the image, a hot air balloon can be spotted above the tall trees.Ours: This statement is false. The declarative sentence and the misleading phrase "can be spotted" make it sound like the object exists in the image, when it doesn't.Instruction (Existent Element Manipulation):Is the woman in the blue pants and pink shirt sitting on the floor?MiniGPT4: Yes, that is the woman in the blue pants and pink shirt sitting on the floor. She is looking at the camera. There is a christmas tree in the room, a fireplace and two chairs in front of it. The man in the red shirt is standing … LLaVA: Yes, the woman is sitting on the floor in front of a Christmas tree. InstructBLIP: Yes, the woman in the blue pants and pink shirt is sitting on the floor. MMGPT: Yes, the woman in the blue pants and pink shirt is sitting on the floor. Ours: The image information does not provide information about a woman sitting on the floor wearing blue pants and pink shirt. Introduction Significant progress has been made in the field of natural language processing, leading to the development of models that can comprehend and follow instructions given natural language inputs [36; 10; 26; 5]. These models harness the power of large language models (LLM) and rely on high-quality instruction data. Similarly, efforts have been made to introduce similar capabilities to multi-modal models. GPT4 [27] has demonstrated impressive performance in multi-modal conversations with humans, yet the techniques contributing to its extraordinary capabilities remain opaque. As a result, several large multi-modal models (LMMs) have recently emerged [39; 23; 10; 8], such as MiniGPT4 [39] and LLaVA [23], both utilize the Vicuna [7] as the language generator but with different vision encoders [28; 16]. InstructBLIP [8] is initialized from a pre-trained BLIP-2 [15] while Multimodal-GPT (MMGPT) [10] is built on Flamingo [1; 3]. A recent study [14] revealed that the hallucination issue of LLM, although not desired, is inherited by these LMMs [39; 23; 10; 8]. Hallucination, a major ethical concern associated with LLMs [4], can lead to harmful consequences, especially when users without adequate domain knowledge over-rely on these increasingly convincing language models. In the context of LMM hallucinations, the model There is no mention of a dog or a ball in the given image. Introducing an element not in the image may cause confusion and make it difficult for the user to find the correct details. LRV-Instruction Dataset(Ours) Finetune There is a dog playing with a ball on the shore. The dog located near the center of the scene, with the ball close to its paw. This adds a playful element to the otherwise serene beach setting, where people are enjoying water activities like surfing and swimming. The image is a photo of a group of three people surfing on the ocean. They are wearing black wet suits and have their boards on their heads. The sky in the background is a light blue color with white clouds. Figure 1: Given an image and human instruction as the input, we introduce GPT4-Assisted Visual Instruction Evaluation (GAVIE) to assess the output from current LMMs, such as MiniGPT4 and LLaVA. BLUE represents LMMs can not accurately follow human instructions while RED means they suffer from the hallucination problem. We can generate a more robust answer after finetuning MiniGPT4 on our proposed LRV-Instruction dataset. can generate descriptions with conflicting information to the given image. For instance, as shown in Fig. 1 (highlighted in red), existing LMMs [39; 23; 8; 10] tend to describe nonexistent objects such as a "dog" engaging in a nonexisting activity like "playing with a ball". Additionally, the model may generate long image descriptions without following human instructions (highlighted in blue). What are the likely causes of these hallucinations? As current LMMs are built on strong LLMs, they may over-rely on language priors and generate words more likely to go together with the instruction text regardless of the image content. What's more, LMMs, such as MiniGPT4 [39] and LLaVA [23], employ synthetic instruction data for training, which are generally long and involve nonexistent objects, activities, or relationships in the image. Why can't LMMs accurately follow human instructions? We conjecture it is due to the lack of diversity in their training data. For example, MiniGPT4 [39] is only instruct tuning with four instruction templates designed for image captioning tasks. Though MMGPT [10] and InstructBLIP [8] combine several datasets as the instruction tuning data, their instructions and answers are still based on a few templates. To address these challenges, we present LRV-Instruction, a large and diverse visual instruction benchmark. Our benchmark consists of 120k visual instructions generated by GPT4, taking inspiration from the success of recent GPT models in text-annotation tasks [24]. Unlike previous studies that focused on limited tasks and pre-defined templates created by human experts [39; 8; 10], LRV-Instruction covers 16 vision-language tasks with open-ended instructions and answers, as shown in Fig. 3 and Tab. 2a. As observed by [18], current LMMs tend to answer "Yes" for any instructions presented to the model, even when the proper answer should be "No". Some models even answer with "Yes" for over 90% of the negative testing examples during their evaluation. Our investigation reveals that most LMMs are finetuned on unbalanced datasets containing only positive instructions (Tab. 1). To enable LMMs to respond to human instructions more faithfully, we design LRV-Instruction to include both negative and positive instructions for robust instruction tuning. Our negative instructions are generated at two semantic levels ( Fig. 2): (i) Nonexistent Element Manipulation and (ii) Existent Element Manipulation in two different formats, Declarative and Interrogative. To improve the robustness and flexibility of the evaluation on visual instruction tuning, we propose GPT4-Assisted Visual Instruction Evaluation (GAVIE) to assess the LMM output in two different aspects: Relevancy to evaluate the instruction-following performance and Accuracy to measure the visual hallucination in the LMM output. GAVIE does not require human-annotated groundtruth answers [29] and can be easily adapted to different instruction formats instead of specific designs in [18]. We empirically evaluate four publicly available LMMs [39; 23; 8; 10] on our benchmark and found that existing LMMs seriously hallucinate when prompted with our negative instructions. We further verify the effectiveness of our LRV-Instruction by finetuning MiniGPT4 [39] on this more balanced data. Our instruct-tuned MiniGPT4 suffers much less from hallucination and achieves state-of-the-art performance compared to the original MiniGPT4, LLaVA [23], InstructBLP [8] and MMGPT [10] on both our evaluation set and public benchmarks [18 ; 11]. We also observe that Existent Element Manipulation instructions are more challenging than Nonexistent Element Manipulation instructions for LMMs. Furthermore, a robust model performance requires a balanced ratio between positive and negative instances. To sum up, our contributions are three-fold: • We build LRV-Instruction, a large and diverse dataset containing 120k visual instructions, with 16 vision and language tasks and negative instructions in different semantic levels and styles. • We propose GAVIE, a novel approach to evaluate visual instruction tuning without requiring groundtruth answers and pre-designed instruction formats. • We conduct comprehensive experiments to investigate the hallucination of current LMMs. The empirical study validates the effectiveness of LRV-Instruction for robust visual instruction tuning. Related Works (Pos) Object Attribute Detection Describe the girl's hair color and whether she is wearing any accessory on her wrist. (Pos) Visual Entailment Verify if this statement is correct: "The scene takes place in a rural area." (Pos) VCR What appears to be the purpose of the green street sign? (Pos) Object Detection What objects are on toddler's feet? (Pos) Activity Recognition What is the primary activity happening in this image, involving a man and dogs? (Pos) Referential Expression Grounding Identify the "a yellow ball behind a giraffe ornament" in the image using the bounding box information. (Pos) OCR What is the number written on the lead snowboarder? matching. Alternatively, [18] converts the hallucination into a binary classification problem. However, it requires the input questions to follow specific templates, such as "Is there a/an
